Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Enhanced Water Recovery at the Energy-Water Nexus: Towards Water-Efficient Cooling Systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact and commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is technology that can provide a transformational reduction in how much freshwater power plants and industrial processes utilize for their cooling needs. One of the US's largest water withdrawal uses is power plants, which account for 39% of total US freshwater withdrawals, mostly for cooling. Cooling towers account for most of the water consumption of the power industry (~1 trillion gallons per year). The product addresses this problem by capturing water from cooling tower plumes so that the water can be re-used. This enables reduction of consumption of water drawn by the power plant (through re-use) by 20%, which means large cost savings to the plants themselves and large savings of water for the community they operate in, allowing that water to be utilized for other important uses.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to develop a commercial proof-of-concept of water capture technology for cooling towers used in power plants and industrial processes. The novel technology uses electric fields to ionize the air around a cooling tower outlet, charge the escaping water leaving cooling towers and direct the water toward a mesh-based collector, where it collects and drips toward a collection tank on the periphery of the cooling tower. Throughout Phase I of the SBIR, the research will focus on verifying the quantity of collectable water droplets in the plumes of the cooling towers, developing durable electrode and collector designs that meet both our performance and stability requirements, and analyzing the collected water quality. Discussions with initial customers have set quantitative success metrics for each of the aforementioned aspects of the Phase I research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Infinite Cooling has developed a novel technology that uses electric fields to capture the water plumes leaving evaporative cooling towers and recycle it for re-use, greatly reducing the freshwater consumption of industrial processes such as power generation. The US's largest water withdrawal use is for power plants, which account for 39% of total US freshwater withdrawals, and the vast majority of this water is used for cooling. Additionally, cooling towers account for most of the water consumption of the power industry (~1 trillion gallons per year). Infinite Cooling's NSF SBIR Phase I Project: Enhanced Water Recovery at the Energy-Water Nexus: Towards Water-Efficient Cooling Systems, developed a Gen 1 design of the collection technology and performed field testing on a 20MW cogeneration power plant. 

 

The Phase I program developed the water collection panels and custom electrodes to collect the plume escaping a cooling tower's exhaust using a lab-based water plume setup. We then installed a pilot on 20MW power plant cooling tower cell and conducted testing on efficiency and water quality in typical operating conditions. We also estimated pressure drop effects on the customer's cooling towers and showed they were small. We finally designed and tested the viability and durability of our custom electrical insulators and other critical system-level components. We achieved all the technical goals we proposed in the application and validated our initial proof of concept.

 

In Phase II, we propose to further develop a new design that was invented by the company and has the potential of addressing all the technical limitations and customer concerns that were identified during Phase I. We will perform systematic experimental studies to optimize various parameters in the system to make it viable in real applications. Secondly, we will focus on materials choice and durability and also design a customer-friendly control panel that integrates our system into the customer's control system. Finally, we will take our optimal design from lab R&D and build a new pilot on a partner facility that has agreed to host it. We will complete the field testing on-site at the partner plant and collect live operational data. This data will further validate our design and will also be an effective marketing tool for customers.

 


Last Modified: 02/24/2020
Modified by: Karim Khalil

    Infinite Cooling
    Public Domain
    Karim Khalil
    Infinite Cooling Phase I Pilot Install
